Image 1 of 10 Overview Frederick Douglass was a 19th century abolitionist, suffragist, writer, editor and statesman. He is, of course, best known for his work against slavery and for equal rights for all. Overview Frederick Douglass was a 19th century abolitionist, suffragist, writer, editor and statesman. Photo: Jaap Buitendijk, HOEP Image 3 of 10 Literacy When he was 12, the owner's sister-in-law taught him to read and write. He began classes for his peers, which were wildly successful until they were broken up. Literacy When he was 12, the owner's sister-in-law taught him to read and write. Image 4 of 10 Escape At 20, Douglass had already tried to escape multiple times, and he was already in love with a free woman, Anna Murray. He finally succeeded in getting to New York City and freedom, mostly by train. This week, in an address honoring Black History Month. Pres. Trump said this about Frederick Douglass: 
"I am very proud now that we have a museum on the National Mall where people can learn about Reverend King, so many other things, Frederick Douglass is an example of somebody who's done an amazing job and is getting recognized more and more, I notice." 
In an apparent attempt to clarify, his press secretary, Scott Spicer, said this: 
"I think he wants to highlight the contributions that he has made. And I think through a lot of the actions and statements that he's going to make, I think the contributions of Frederick Douglass will become more and more." 
Many speculated that neither one was entirely clear who Douglass was, or that he was dead. 
To clarify, here are some things to know about Frederick Douglass. Need to Know
